### Section: 17.2 Collider Experiments:

Collider experiments have been a crucial tool in the study of high energy physics. These experiments involve the use of particle accelerators to collide particles at high energies, allowing for the study of their properties and interactions. In this section, we will explore the various collider experiments that have been conducted, their results, and their significance in the field of high energy physics.

#### 17.2a Collider Experiments in Particle Physics

Collider experiments in particle physics have been instrumental in advancing our understanding of the fundamental building blocks of matter. These experiments involve the use of particle accelerators to collide particles at high energies, allowing for the study of their properties and interactions. One of the most well-known collider experiments is the ZEUS experiment, which was conducted at the DESY laboratory in Hamburg, Germany.

The ZEUS experiment was designed to study the properties of the Z boson, a fundamental particle that mediates the weak interaction between particles. The experiment involved the use of a particle detector to measure the properties of the Z boson, such as its mass and decay modes. The results of the ZEUS experiment have been crucial in confirming the predictions of the Standard Model of particle physics and have provided valuable insights into the nature of the Z boson.

Another important collider experiment in particle physics is the NA62 experiment, which was conducted at the CERN laboratory in Geneva, Switzerland. The NA62 experiment was designed to study the rare decay of the K+ meson into a pion and two neutrinos. This decay is of particular interest as it is predicted by the Standard Model, but has never been observed. The results of the NA62 experiment have provided the first evidence for this decay, with a significance of 3.9 standard deviations.

The OPERA experiment, also conducted at the CERN laboratory, was designed to study the properties of the tauon, a fundamental particle that is a member of the lepton family. The experiment involved the use of a neutrino detector to measure the properties of the tauon, such as its mass and decay modes. The results of the OPERA experiment have been crucial in confirming the predictions of the Standard Model and have provided valuable insights into the nature of the tauon.

#### 17.2b Collider Experiments in Cosmology

In addition to studying fundamental particles, collider experiments have also been used in the field of cosmology. The Dark Matter Time Projection Chamber (DMTPC) experiment, for example, was designed to study the properties of dark matter, a mysterious substance that makes up about 27% of the universe. The experiment involved the use of a time projection chamber to detect dark matter particles, such as the WIMP (Weakly Interacting Massive Particle).

The DMTPC experiment published its first results in 2010, setting a spin-dependent cross section limit on the interaction between dark matter and nucleons. This result has provided valuable insights into the nature of dark matter and has paved the way for future experiments, such as the Dark Matter Time Projection Chamber II (DMTPC II), which aims to improve the sensitivity of the experiment and provide more precise measurements.

#### 17.2c Collider Experiments in the Future

As technology continues to advance, collider experiments are expected to become even more sophisticated and powerful. The Future Circular Collider (FCC) study, for example, is currently developing and evaluating three accelerator concepts for a potential future collider. These concepts include the FCC-ee, a lepton collider that would operate at center-of-mass collision energies between 90 and 350 GeV, and the FCC-hh, a hadron collider that would operate at center-of-mass collision energies up to 100 TeV.

The FCC-ee, in particular, has the potential to provide valuable insights into the properties of the Z, W, Higgs, and top particles, as well as the strong interaction. It could also search for new particles coupling to the Higgs and electroweak bosons up to scales of  = 7 and 100 TeV. Furthermore, measurements of invisible or exotic decays of the Higgs and Z bosons could provide evidence for dark matter or heavy neutrinos with masses below 70 GeV.

In conclusion, collider experiments have been a crucial tool in the study of high energy physics, providing valuable insights into the fundamental building blocks of matter and the nature of the universe. As technology continues to advance, these experiments are expected to become even more sophisticated and powerful, paving the way for groundbreaking discoveries in the field of high energy physics.
